reviewText:
Early Access Review

Introduction
Flying Tigers: Shadows over China is an arcade dogfighting game set during WWII in China, Burma and India. The 1st American Volunteer Group, nicknamed the Flying Tigers, were a group of US pilots who fought for China during WWII. The game itself is based around this group and the campaign missions are based on real operations that took place during the War. The two factions in the game are the Allies and the Japanese, currently the campaign only lets you fly Ally aircraft but you can fly Japanese aircraft in the other game modes.

Presentation
Flying Tigers is, overall, a good looking game. The graphics aren’t exactly cutting edge and some of the ground textures aren’t brilliant but they get the job done and they do it well. All of the aircraft models look good and, to my eye, look reasonably realistic. For the most part, visual effects are good, I particularly like how bullets actually leave holes in the aircraft. The only visual effect that I thought was sub-par was rain, it doesn’t really fit with the overall look of the game and missions where it’s raining seem to look worse, graphically, than other missions. As for menus and the user interface they’re both very good. The menu is simple and easy to navigate while the UI is useful as well as fully customisable in the sense that anything can be turned on or off as you please.

Game Modes
Flying Tigers features several different ways to play both online and offline. Up first we have the campaign I briefly mentioned earlier, the missions here are all based on real operations during the war but there’s no real storyline to it, each mission is effectively standalone. Currently there are eight missions to play with the rest being released as the game progresses through development. Next we have the offline Dogfighting mode, this mode allows you to choose any aircraft in the game (apart from bombers) to fly and then allows you to choose how many aircraft you want to fight and what type of aircraft you want to fight (currently you can’t pick a selection) as well as what map and weather conditions you want. Similarly to Dogfight there’s the challenge mode, currently there are only two challenges available but these have you destroy as many enemy aircraft you can with a certain aircraft before you’re shot down. The last offline game mode is free flight, the name says it all for this one really. All of the offline game modes have two difficulty levels (Rookie and Normal) with a Hard mode coming later in development. Last, and currently least, we have Online battles featuring up to 16 players, unfortunately the multiplayer seems to be completely dead, only one server came up on the server browser and it was completely empty. Fingers crossed multiplayer will be become more active as the game progresses and more people buy into the game.

GameplayFlying Tigers is very much an arcade dogfighting experience. Obviously the game is centred on air-air combat but there are also ground and naval targets in some of the missions. I must say, combat is a lot of fun, especially when you’re chasing enemies while being chased yourself. All of the aircraft feature at least one forward facing gun and some have backwards facing guns controlled by AI apart from some scripted events. As well as guns there are also bombs and torpedoes used by some of the aircraft to take out the ground and naval targets I mentioned. The main reason this game is more towards the arcade side of things rather than simulation is due to the game’s controls. It’s also an arcade game due to a slow motion ability that you can use (and recharge as it doesn’t last forever) during combat, I had a lot of fun messing around with this ability and it does also make it easier to hit targets which frequently comes in handy.

Controls
The first thing worth mentioning is that you’re given a hell of a lot of choice in the game for input devices. You can either play with: just a mouse, a keyboard and mouse, a gamepad and even a flight stick/HOTAS setup. The main thing which makes this game so much of an arcade game, which I personally don’t like, is the limitations in terms of aircraft manoeuvrability. You can’t bank the plane more than 90° manoeuvres that you can do in other games. The devs have explained that this limitation is there due to limitations with the camera and also to stop us “fiddling with controls unnecessarily” (whatever that means) but the devs have said we may see these limitations removed at some point in the future so fingers crossed. With the most recent update one of these limitations has been removed from the game hence I’ve removed it from my review, hopefully the other one will go too. Other than that issue the controls are great, the planes all feel as responsive as they should (obviously a large bomber is less responsive than a small fighter aircraft).

Audio
Audio is largely very good in Flying Tigers. The sound effects are all very high quality and make the aircraft sound somewhat real. The game’s sound track is good and fits well with the game, definitely gives it an action film kind of feel. Lastly the voice acting in the game is all done reasonably well though there were a couple of times where I was left wondering if the correct accent was used. One thing worth mentioning is that not all of the dialogue lines for the missions are in the game yet since it’s still in Early Access but I imagine these will be added in later updates.

Miscellaneous
The game has already received several different updates and the devs are active on the forums which is nice to see
There are already quite a few different aircraft for both factions with more coming soon
The game already has nine different maps, each with several different weather conditions, with more coming soon
Most aircraft have different paint jobs to choose from though you can’t choose different paint jobs during the campaign (due to the devs wanting to keep the game historically accurate)
If you’d like to see an offline Dogfight, check out my gameplay video:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4sZpZIPumk0

Verdict
Worth Purchasing.

Flying Tigers is a great arcade dogfighting game with good graphics, quite a few different aircraft and plenty of content already. If you enjoy dogfighting games there’s no question you’ll enjoy this one too and it’s only going to get better as it progresses through Early Access.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I should say, I have not been playing flight simulators that much previously, but if you’re heading to start, then FLYING TIGERS: SHADOWS OVER THE CHINA is right for you.
Game of the genre will appreciate both amateurs and beginners, and now I'll tell you why:

Soundtrack. After the game was launched, the first thing I noticed was a soundtrack in the main menu. Without a minor doubt, it was amazing. I enjoyed it while setting the game up. Music in the game itself is quite dynamic and non-irritating as well.

Control. Control can be adjusted by your own, depending on your preferences. You may use either Mouse + Keyboard or the controller. As for me, I started with M + K.
After training flight was over, I got the instructions quite right and dealt with the first task fast enough. By the way, you can also choose among three difficulty levels, from beginner to advanced.

Graphics. Overall, the graphics are good enough; details look pretty realistic and gamma does not make your eyes tired even after few hours of gaming in a row. I was impressed by detalization of aircraft though, each small piece is drawn to the fullest.

Gameplay. There are four different play modes (except multiplayer) in the game. You can fight against other squadrons, escort Allied bombers, and attack ground troops and infantry by yourself using a number of different tricks and techniques.
Each aspect of the game is completely different, there is nothing that makes you bored despite few hours of straight play; most probably, you’d like to go into it again and again.

Multiplayer. The only shortage at the moment is the lack of players in multiplayer. Frankly, I failed to try this mode at all. However, the server will be hopefully filled so we can enjoy the game each night really soon.
Keep in mind, the game is still in the early access. Developers improve the game consistently, so new updates and all the fixes are coming out in time.
If you’re still thinking whether to purchase the game or not, you’d better do. You won’t regret!

Early Access Review

Amazing plane game, if you hate ubisoft/loved blazing angels you this game is for you. It has amazing mouse & keyboard controls, amazing gameplay and graphics.

The planes fly so well, for example if you were to go up really high, your plane would stall (Pilot also will start to blackout if you do an immelman, which is cool). Then if you charged down, your plane would speed up rapidly. If that made you closer to the enemy plane you were fighting, you would do more damage. Another thing that is helpful to some is the Trazertime thing. It helps with aim quite a bit if you have shakey hands or are new, I don't use it myself, because I think it's unfair to the AI. The Trazertime only works in singleplayer though, do be warned.

Now for graphics: This game is well optimized and I have never had a crash before or any lag. I think the explosions are incredible, and if you drive through it you get oil on your cockpit. Sending a plane into some trees and then seeing it explode and stay on fire for quite a while is loads of fun. If you land on the water, you can see that they took the time to make it nice and have wildlife in it [like whales, yay!]. The planes look so real with their cool paint jobs, even some fictional ones, like a zero painted with german symbols on it (not swastikas).

It also has multiplayer, which I do not remember blazing angels having, as well as a beatable campaign which was also lacking in blazing angels (darn you ice caves mission!). I must add again though, the controls are perfect.

Important note: You DO NOT need a controller for this game.

Early Access Review

Review: Flying Tigers

What do you get?
In modern day gaming, it is all too common for you to pay top dollar for AAA games, expecting weeks of exciting new content with pitch perfect gameplay. And more often than less, getting disappointed with rushed and unpolished gameplay and content, and you feeling like you got robbed of your money and time.
It is a breath of fresh air to play games like Flying Tigers. It is one of those games where the price you pay and the experience you get are perfectly matched and every minute play is time well spent. It is these type of games that makes me excited for the gaming community.

My System:
I ran Flying Tigers on my Windows Desktop with the following:
•	GeForce GTX 960 4gb
•	Intel Core i5-4440 @ 3.1GHz
•	16gb of DDR3 RAM

The Basics:
Performance - With my rig, with maxed out graphics, at 1080p, I got solid and stable 60 frames per second with frames dropping slightly during high content instances during campaign but nothing visually noticeable.

Joystick needed?? - Yes. Or at least a console remote. Keyboard and mouse inputs are not bad, and definitely playable, but I found myself on numerous occasions overshooting the target, flying in circles around ground targets and getting frustrated over simple controls.

Graphics - Well-polished and surprisingly on par graphics even compared to some AAA games. It is nothing ground-breaking and certainly won’t stand out as something different. But from small details on the plane to the massive open worlds filled with contest, they get it right.

Audio - To put it clear and simple, from machine guns blasting to numerous different characters and accents, the quality is excellent and coincides with the game perfectly. Even the main menu soundtrack sets the mood for the action packed gameplay.

General Gameplay - The game runs smoothly, looks great, sounds great and plays great. With almost no bugs or crashes, this type of gameplay is what every other gaming studio should strive to achieve at launch date.


Single Player:
Single player consists of of:
Campaign
Dogfight
Select Challenge
Free Flight
The Campaign consists out of 12 mission, which have huge variety in where you play, the type of mission, planes and weaponry. It is both entertaining and well written. But the progression from mission to mission does not flow from one to the next well enough as to keep you wanting to play one more. Yet it adds something new to the WW2 series as you play in locations set in China-Burma-India, which is accompanied with excellent voice acting, realistic gameplay and outcomes.
Dogfight and Select challenge are basically the Campaign without the voice acting and missing introduction, but add a couple of hours of extra flying fun to the mix.

Multiplayer:
Multiplayer consists of:
Join Online Battle
Host Online Battle
Steam Leader boards
Pilot Record
At the moment, there are minimal players online as it is almost impossible to find a match. But as the game is in early release, I expect the number of players to exponentially increase.

Something to think about:
You are getting what you are paying for here. This is a WW2 aerial combat game. And that’s it. There is a Single player and a Multiplayer and it follows the usual old recipe of flying around trying to shoot down as many enemy planes or destroying ground targets. It’s nothing new or revolutionary, but it doesn’t have to be. It’s a well polish game that delivers much than what you expect. It reminds me of the good old days when games use to be simpler and more to the point. And that’s exactly what Flying Tiger’s is.


Will I play it for more than a week?
At the moment no. As it stands any average PC gamer will be able to complete the Campaign and other single player elements in under a week, BUT when the multiplayer segment gets up and running I am sure that countless more hours will be spent flying over the beautiful China-Burma-India landscapes trying to gun down opponents.

Early Access Review

Flying Tigers is a fun, exhilarating, and challenging dog fighting game that takes place during the events of World War 2. It has a killer opening song; fantastic controls that are hard to master, but easy to pickup, an intuitive HUD, and graphics that are not only charming; but also feel very true to the era is depicts.

Controls:
The controls work flawlessly on mouse and keyboard, but if you want the ultimate experience feel free to use your flight stick; my 10 year old Logitech joystick with rudder was supported out of the box, so just about any will do. When using the mouse to control the plane, the experience feels flawless and once you pair it up with the keyboard commands like barrel rolls and time slows, the combination really comes together to provide an experience that both feels natural and allows for a very high skill ceiling

Game modes:
Flying Tigers has a fully fleshed out campaign that really draws you into the atmosphere as you take part in dog fights against some of the historical bad guys of World War 2; it also has a multiplayer, which isn't currently as packed as it deserves, but when you get into an online fight it's all adrenaline.

Conclusion:
The game does what it says, it provides a challenging, rewarding, exhilarating, historical dog fighting experience. If you like dog fighting games you should absolutely get Flying Tigers, it's an example of what so many dog fighting games set out to do and fail.

Do you remember the days of playing Ace Combat on the Playstation console? Do you miss GOOD aerial dogfights and heartpounding action in a fighter plane game?  Well I believe Flying Tigers: Shadows Over China (FT:SOC) to be the game you've been pining for.

Essentially FT:SOC comes across as an arcade flight game where you pilot various World War 2 aircraft that took place during various missions around China. It is worth noting that the developer coded their own game engine (SkyLight3D) just to make this game the way they wanted, so immediate kudos goes to them for that.

It's actually a great looking game, for the cost I fully expected it to not have much detail in the textures and be more focused on the gameplay but the developers seem to have got the balance right between the two.  I play this on full cinematic graphic settings at 1080p and it runs smooth as a hot knife through butter, even when recording/streaming gameplay it rarely gets even a whisker close to 40fps and stays around 60+ fairly regularly. (FYI I'm running an AMD 8 core, 8Gb ram, 2Gb R9 380 PC)

The solo campaign is pretty good so far, I'm currently 4 missions in and although I'm no history buff, I get the feeling that the missions have been crafted with quite a considerable amount of detail and thus far they have been great fun, trying the different variants of planes helps keep things very fresh.

Multiplayer however is currently a little bit lacking due to slow traffic, I did try and host a game for a while but sadly nobody dropped in but it definately works and I feel this would be a killer game to play with a bunch of friends!

The settings are really feature filled too with nearly every option avaliable either in the pre-game config loader or in-game via the keybindings where you can even attach a proper fightstick to give better control to your plane.

Overall this game is definately worth buying and if you are a fan of this sort of game I recommend you buy into it, especially as it's only in early access right now and the developers are planning to put in more content.

I'm going to recommend this game, but with some caveats:

1. If you're looking for a sim, this game isn't for you.

Dogfighting, hitting ground targets, torpedoing ships, strafing soldiers on the ground, shooting vickers machine guns from the topside of bombers and so on.

Note to developers: If it had a nose cam it would be a huge improvement. It would actually make me feel like I had more control of my plane and improve the overall experience.

FLYING TIGERS: SHADOWS OVER CHINA is one of many World War 2 flying simulators on Steam. So why should you buy this game instead of playing other Early Access flying sims?

First off is the early good signs of polish, even with Early Access, the planes and environment look fantastic and meticulously designed. The bullets and bombs feel like they have destructive impact. When enemy planes are damaged, they show debris falling off and die in spectacular explosions. The polished voice acting will make you feel like you're fighting and flying among the Allies. There are rarely games that take the fight to the Japanese and Flying Tigers helps break the hold on Europe-centric WW2 games.

A handy life bar is present for every enemy, indicating how much you have to do to bring down the enemy. It takes a bit to get used to the controls, but who said piloting and fighting against the Axis was easy? You even get slow-mo to line up your shots and acrobatic moves to evade fire.

If you're tired of the single player, the other modes, including dogfights, multiplayer, and free flying will give you flight sim goodness. Face off in custom planes against an enemy to practice dogfighting skills.

The best part, even with all the content for only $9.99, the game is still in Early Access, meaning there's still MUCH more free content to come! More planes are very visibly seen to be coming in the selection screen, so at half price this game is a steal!
